results.title: A Saucer of water for the birds
results.brief_description: The unusual technique of sand animation is used to tell the story of a woman and her granddaughter. It starts with them sitting at the kitchen table playing cards. As the cards are shuffled and cut, the film cuts between pre-war Poland, Europe in the Holocaust, the woman’s childhood and the present. The old woman’s homeland is evoked as a world the child strives to create from anecdotes. The woman’s present is shown as one etched with darkness of her family’s experience of the Holocaust.

results.title: A Saucer of water for the birds
results.brief_description: An animated short. A woman and her grandmother sit together playing cards. As they are shuffled and dealt, the film cuts between pre-war Poland, Europe during the Holocaust, the woman’s childhood, and the present. A meditation on the relationship between public history and personal memory, as it is played out in the dynamics of the family.

results.title: A Salute to Mel Blanc
results.brief_description: This is a tribute collection of classic cartoons dedicated to the remarkable voice of Mel Blanc. He was the voice of so many well known cartoon characters including Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck, Porky Pig, Pepe Le Pew, Yosemite Sam, Tweety and Sylvester and each of these selected cartoons features at least one of Mel Blanc’s characterisations. Interestingly, the dialogue was recorded before the animators did their work meaning that Mel Blanc had to imagine and create the action from a series of sketches. This is no mean feat and requires a lot of skill and energy. Mel Blanc died in 1989 but his voice lives on in the much-loved Looney Tunes and Merrie Melodies cartoons which are still showing around the world today. Suitable viewing for all the family.

results.title: A Salute to Friz Freleng
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures and Isadore Freleng
results.brief_description: Born Isadore Freleng in 1906 in Missouri (died 1995) but better known as Friz Freleng, this Academy Award winner cartoonist/animator joined Warner Bros studios as head animator in 1930 and it is here that he created the majority of his over 300 cartoons, mainly for Merrie Melodies and Looney Tunes. His brand of humour and whacky cartoon characters are loved and adored world-wide and across all age groups. This video pays tribute to Freleng by showing eight of his more prominent and well-known cartoons mainly from the 1950s period and include those evergreen favourites Sylvester and Tweety, Bugs Bunny, Yosemite Sam, and Speedy Gonzales. Three of the eight cartoons shown are Oscar winners: “Birds anonymous”, “Speedy Gonzales” and “Knighty knight Bugs”.

results.title: A Safety net
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Battle for the planet”.
The presenter of this program, Professor Eddie Ayensu of Ghana, is a leading African commentator on development issues. His concern in this program is what he sees as the damage which food aid does to African economics. To him, this aid creates a psychological dependence in the minds of farmers and acts as a disincentive to their own production. Ayensu says food aid was originally intended to provide African countries with room to manoeuvre, but now unwanted foods (such as sugar) is virtually being dumped. He looks at the staple foods in Africa such as Cassava, fish and fruit and makes the point that if Western aid went into improving productivity in these industries, African food production would be much more efficient and better able to feed the population.

results.title: A Run for your money
results.creator_credit: Charles Cahill and Charles Cahill and Associates
results.brief_description: A Japanese uses about one quarter of the energy used by an American. When fuel economy counts, it is important to watch driving habits, it is also important to use smaller cars, not carry heavy things unless necessary, not over utilise air conditioning and make sure that the cars used receive regular maintenance.

results.title: A Rosewood daydream
results.brief_description: This is the name of a Toronto folk group - two young men, a blue-eyed woman, and a guitar. They sing outdoors, indoors, wherever there’s a friendly audience. Most of the “with it” listeners in this film are the old folks in a home for the aged in St. John’s, Newfoundland. To them the group sings old songs of the sea, and a popular tune, Louis Collins, by Mississippi John Hurt.

results.title: A Rose for Emily
results.creator_credit: Chubbuck Cinema Company, Lyndon Chubbuck and H Kaye Dyal
results.brief_description: When Miss Emily Grierson, the town’s aristocrat, was young, her tyrannical father drove her suitors away. After his death, Emily succumbed to the advances of a man beneath her station and this film shows the consequences of this event. This film is a twentieth century Gothic tale dealing in the mysterious and the macabre and is of interest to both film and literature classes. Stars Angelica Huston and John Carradine and adapted from the short story by William Faulkner. Narrated by John Houseman.

results.title: A Room with a view
results.creator_credit: Ismail Merchant, Merchant Ivory Productions and James Ivory
results.brief_description: Based on E M Forster’s classic novel, this film tells the story of a young English couple who encounter passion in Italy and, defying the Victorian conventions of their elders, dare to be true to their emotions and each other. Stars Helena Bonham-Carter, Maggie Smith, Denholm Elliot and Julian Sands.
